column1: Diuretics are medications that increase urine output
Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, act on the ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the nephron
This segment is crucial for reabsorbing sodium and chloride, and blocking it leads to increased excretion of these ions into the urine
Thiazide diuretics, like hydrochlorothiazide, inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule
By blocking reabsorption of sodium and chloride, thiazides increase the osmolarity of the urine, which enhances water excretion
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, such as acetazolamide, reduce the production of carbonic acid in the proximal convoluted tubule
This decrease inhibits sodium bicarbonate reabsorption, leading to a more acidic urine and increased water excretion
Each type of diuretic targets a different part of the nephron to alter the concentration of solutes in the urine and consequently increase urine volume
Understanding these mechanisms helps in the appropriate use of diuretics for managing conditions like hypertension and edema
